summary: This document is a chain of emails between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutors discussing the upcoming indictment of Ghislaine Maxwell. The primary email, sent on June 12, 2020, outlines the charges against Maxwell (conspiracy and substantive counts related to the Mann Act) and seeks legal advice on a technical question regarding overt acts and state statutes. The subsequent emails coordinate a brief phone call to discuss the matter.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the upcoming indictment. Described as Jeffrey Epstein's former girlfriend, charged with recruiting and grooming minor girls for abuse by Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the perpetrator for whom Maxwell allegedly recruited and groomed minor victims.

connections.description: Described as Epstein's former girlfriend who played a role in recruiting and grooming minor girls to be abused by him.

events.title: Prosecution Team Reaches Out for Legal Consultation
events.description: A prosecutor emails a colleague to schedule a call to discuss legal questions regarding the upcoming indictment of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Team Follow-up on Maxwell Indictment
events.description: Multiple emails are exchanged coordinating a time for a phone call to discuss the technical legal issue related to the Maxwell indictment.

events.title: Call Scheduled
events.description: A time of 10 AM is confirmed for a brief phone call to discuss the Maxwell indictment questions.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was preparing to indict Ghislaine Maxwell in June 2020.
The planned charges included conspiracy under the Mann Act and substantive counts related to recruiting and grooming minor girls for Jeffrey Epstein.
Prosecutors had a specific, time-sensitive legal question about whether they needed to identify a particular state statute violated for each victim to allege overt acts in the conspiracy.
The email chain shows internal coordination among prosecutors just before the indictment was made public.
